"The imbalance in mobile phone consumption is another example of a relatively small group of individuals dominating the consumption of a particular resource. The United States, with less than 5 percent of the world’s population, consumes about 23 percent of the world’s daily oil production, according to American government figures. Japan, Germany and Italy, whose populations together make up less than 4 percent of the world’s total, accounted for 31 percent of global natural gas imports in 2010, according to the International Energy Agency."

This is a misleading comparison, given that wireless bandwith is by its nature a local, not global, resource. Unused bandwith in, for example, the San Francisco area cannot be shipped to mobile phone users in Cairo, and carriers in San Francisco cannot import wireless bandwith from other areas of the world.

Pray tell Brian, what was that "greatness"? Surely you do not mean that it can be found in the America of the 17th, 18th, 19th and 20th Centuries, when America: (1) annihilated the indigenous population and its diverse cultures and dispossessed them of most of their lands (leaving them what lands were considered of little value) as part of manifest destiny; (2) enslaved more than a million Africans in order to enrich and wait on their white owners and their guests; (3) invaded, bombed and/or occupied defenseless, non-threatening nations like the Philippines, Cuba, Mexico, Dominican Republic, Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, Lebanon, Grenada, Nicaragua and Iraq, thereby causing their citizenry to suffer grievously from the many deaths, disabling wounds, and destroyed homes and factories; (4) intervened covertly through the CIA or its proxies in order to bring down democratically elected foreign governments not to the liking of the U.S. (see e.g., Guatemala and Iran in early 1980s); (5)  served as the world's biggest arms supplier and "greatest" merchant of death; and (6) gobbled up more of world's natural resources than any other nation. With the exceptions of America's arguable "greatness" in helping to defeat fascism and Nazism in WWII and to rebuild war-torn Europe and to end Serbian irredentism in Bosnia and Kosovo in the 1990s, all of its other interventions were intended to facilitate the profitability of corporate America--hardly something to start waving the flag about.

This is a wonderful article that illuminates the difficult role of first lady. Every president needs someone in his life who will watch his back, tell him truths that others are afraid to, and who knows who his real friends are. The country needs the first lady (or first spouse) to do this, as evidently thankless as the role may be.
From my observations, Michelle has been flawless-- amazingly so. What I would love to know is whether Hilary and she ever talk about these things. The opportunity is certainly there.

Another completely 'hidden' cost is the ecological externalities that come with the manufacture, shipping and even use of these products. While Pogue is right to expose the fallacy of these 'price breakdowns' - what we certainly don't pay for is all of the environmental damage that accrues as a result of these nifty gadgets.

If we had to introduce the costs of toxins making up their insides, the CO2 emissions of charging them and the energy needed to melt the plastic, power the trucks, operate the robots, ETC, then we'd really have to jack up the prices.

They are indeed "powerful, beautiful machines available to the masses". But in order for them to exist "at prices that millions can afford" we are forced to pass on their 'TRUE' cost to future generations. It is the real awe of today's digital age. One we pay for dearly with each new cellphone upgrade.

As sad as it may be, the idea that as the first black woman who was the First Lady, and fearful of making a mistake is absolutely spot on.  My generation all thought, as a teenager and young adult of the 60's and 70's that we'd come further than that.  Unfortunately, the election of President Obama has proven that wrong. Racial prejudice, subtle and blatant, is clearly alive and well in the United States.

In some ways we've only inched our way out of the Civil Rights Era.

And the First Lady, the term first spouse is simply arcane, had and has every reason to believe that some American's were and/are waiting for her to screw up.

It takes a special woman to be First Lady. From Abigail Adams & Dolly Madison to 20th/21st Century standouts from Presidents Wilson to President Obama.

Edith Wilson held the country together while her husband was ill; while
Eleanor Roosevelt was the prototype for the modern first lady.

Lady Bird Johnson took a back seat but was influential. Pat Nixon supported a woman's right to choose and insisted on her husband appoint a woman to the Supreme Court.

Rosalyn Carter was the overtly strong Southern woman who represented a change during a time of woman's rights.

Betty Ford was elegant. A woman who believed in her power/ability and a woman's ability. But because of circumstances represented the pain millions of men and woman felt due to drugs and alcohol.

Nancy Reagan was strong willed and shaped her husbands staff.

Hillary Clinton, if it weren't for her - Bill clinton would never have been elected.

Michelle Obama, like Hillary - is a smart, tough woman who knows what's what and what's right. She fights against those who oppose her husband, fights against those in the administration that oppose who he is, she fights for policies that are right, and fights for their joint vision.
Mrs. Obama is a realist; that is all.

There is something really sad about Mrs. Obama's reported thinking that "everyone was waiting for a black woman to make a mistake". Have we actually progressed so little since the Civil Rights Era?

It seems to me that being First Lady (or First Spouse, for that matter) is a thankless, damned-if-you-do, damned if you-don't sort of job that leaves no room for another career of one's choosing. I, for one, am grateful, however, that each President has had a partner who has seen him not only as the supreme leader of our country and perhaps the whole of the free world, but also as the man she married, keeping the ego that anyone in such a position would naturally develop in check.
